title: Hi, I’m Annabelle
text: I’m a Financial Analyst. I specialize in transforming complex information into clear, engaging, and actionable insights.

title: Hi, I’m Annabelle
text:
About Me
I hold a  Bachelor’s degree in Business Administration from University of Oregon, where I developed a strong foundation in finance, analytics, and strategic thinking.

title: Hi, I’m Annabelle
text:
Let’s Connect
You can email me or connect on LinkedIn.

Welcome to my portfolio.

title: Marketing Analytics
text:
Below are selected projects that highlight my experience applying marketing analytics to real-world challenges. These projects reflect my ability to combine statistical tools, campaign data, and strategic thinking to inform decisions and drive results.
Whether developing dashboards, analyzing campaign performance, or uncovering insights through SEO and web analytics, each project is rooted in turning complex marketing data into clear, actionable strategies.

title: Marketing Analytics
text:
What You’ll Find

Campaign Performance Analysis: Evaluating the effectiveness of digital marketing efforts using data.
Data Visualization: Turning raw datasets into intuitive dashboards and reports.
Marketing Mix & Attribution: Exploring how different channels contribute to success.
Customer & Market Insights: Using analytics to better understand user behavior and optimize experiences.

title: Customer Segmentation Using Clustering
text:
Overview
In this analysis, customer data was segmented using clustering algorithms to identify meaningful groups. These segments informed targeting strategies and personalization efforts.




Learning Outcomes

Clean and prepare customer-level data.

Apply clustering techniques to group similar customers.

Interpret clusters to define marketing personas.

Recommend tailored messaging strategies.

Support targeted campaign development.




Key Skills Gained

K-means clustering

Data preprocessing

Customer profiling

Market segmentation strategy

R or Python for machine learning

title: Marketing Funnel Attribution Model
text:
Overview
This project developed a marketing attribution model to assign credit to touchpoints throughout the conversion journey. The insights supported channel optimization and budget reallocation.




Learning Outcomes

Track multi-touch customer journeys.

Model attribution using first-touch, last-touch, and linear approaches.

Visualize funnel performance.

Quantify channel impact on conversion.

Guide future campaign investment decisions.




Key Skills Gained

Attribution modeling

Funnel analysis

Data visualization

Campaign performance analysis

R or Python analytics pipelines

title: SEO Benchmarking Analysis
text:
Overview
This project compared SEO performance across competitors, highlighting keyword gaps, backlink profiles, and content effectiveness. Insights were used to guide an improved content and SEO strategy.




Learning Outcomes

Identify keyword opportunities through competitive research.

Track and compare domain authority and page rankings.

Recommend on-page SEO improvements.

Design a data-driven SEO content strategy.

Visualize competitor positioning.




Key Skills Gained

Keyword research

Web scraping & data cleaning

SEO analysis tools

Data storytelling

Strategy development

title: Résumé
text:
You can view a PDF version of my résumé here.

Professional Summary
Analytical and results-driven finance professional with a Bachelor of Science in Finance and a minor in Economics from the University of Oregon. Currently serving as a Financial Analyst at HD Supply, with a strong track record in P&L management, forecasting, and cost analysis. Demonstrated ability to support cross-functional teams through data-driven insights and strategic recommendations. Previous experience includes roles in supply chain analysis and entrepreneurial ventures, showcasing a unique blend of corporate finance expertise and entrepreneurial acumen. Adept at leveraging Excel and financial tools to drive operational efficiency and cost savings. Passionate about advancing into financial planning and analysis leadership, with long-term goals in real estate investment and business development.


Technical Skills

Programming Languages: R, SQL
Web Technologies: HTML, Quarto, Analytics Tools



Education

Year
College / Department

University of Oregon





Work Experience

Senior Financial Analyst, HD Supply
1/1/2024 – Present

Spearhead nationwide P&L forecasting and reporting for 120+ distribution centers, aligning financial strategy with operational goals.
Partner with executive leadership to deliver high-impact insights that drive multimillion-dollar cost savings and performance improvements.
Navigate advanced reporting systems using SQL, Excel, and Power BI, enabling real-time visibility into financial and operational KPIs.
Lead cross-functional initiatives focused on financial planning, capital allocation, and strategic growth opportunities.

Champion automation and data governance efforts, improving reporting accuracy and reducing manual processes by 40%.




Financial Analyst, HD Supply
1/1/2022 – 12/31/2023

Conducted monthly variance analysis and financial reviews across key business units, ensuring alignment with corporate targets.
Built dynamic forecasting models in Anaplan and Excel to support scenario planning and business case development.
Delivered actionable insights to regional managers, influencing decisions on pricing, staffing, and resource allocation.
Enhanced financial storytelling through interactive dashboards and marketing analytics tools.
Contributed to digital transformation projects, streamlining reporting workflows and improving data accessibility.

title: Professional Summary
Social Media Engagement Analysis
text:
Overview
This analysis examined engagement metrics across multiple social media platforms to identify content trends, audience preferences, and posting strategies that drive performance.




Learning Outcomes

Aggregate and clean social media data.

Identify high-performing content formats.

Understand audience behavior and peak times.

Support social strategy with data-backed recommendations.

Visualize results in an executive summary.




Key Skills Gained

Social analytics

Platform metric APIs

Content performance tracking

Audience insights

Strategic planning

title: Campaign Insights Dashboard
text:
Overview
This project involved building a dashboard to track and visualize marketing campaign performance. Metrics like click-through rate, conversion rate, and ROI were tracked across channels using R and Tableau.




Learning Outcomes

Visualize and monitor key marketing metrics.

Analyze performance trends across multiple campaigns.

Identify high- and low-performing segments.

Communicate insights through interactive visuals.

Develop data-informed recommendations.




Key Skills Gained

Dashboard development

Campaign analytics

Data wrangling in R

Tableau or R Shiny visualization

Performance measurement

title: Strategic Marketing
text: Below is a project that showcase my work in strategic marketing, campaign development, and brand management. The example I highlighted shows how I apply leadership, data-informed decision making, and creative direction to drive marketing success.

title: Strategic Marketing
text:
[Project Title 1: Strategic Campaign Planning]
In this project, I led the development of a comprehensive marketing campaign for [product, service, or initiative]. From audience segmentation to messaging strategy, I managed the full lifecycle of the campaign, aligning it with business objectives and measurable KPIs.
Skills Demonstrated:

Marketing Strategy: Defined objectives and tactics for maximum impact.
Team Coordination: Oversaw collaboration across creative, data, and channel teams.
Performance Tracking: Implemented real-time metrics and post-campaign analysis.
Brand Positioning: Ensured consistency across all touchpoints.

title: Strategic Marketing
text:
[Project Title 2: Brand Audit & Positioning]
This initiative involved conducting a full brand audit for [organization or brand], evaluating its current market perception, competitive landscape, and customer engagement. I synthesized insights into a refreshed brand strategy and visual identity recommendations.
Skills Demonstrated:

Brand Analysis: Audited messaging, tone, and visual identity.
Competitive Benchmarking: Evaluated brand positioning within the market.
Strategic Communication: Developed new value propositions and storytelling elements.
Stakeholder Presentation: Delivered recommendations to senior leadership.

title: Strategic Marketing
text:
[Project Title 3: Product Launch Go-to-Market Plan]
For the release of [new product/service], I created a go-to-market (GTM) strategy from scratch. This included customer journey mapping, channel mix planning, and launch timeline coordination.
Skills Demonstrated:

Go-to-Market Strategy: Developed a clear launch roadmap aligned with buyer needs.
Integrated Marketing: Orchestrated email, paid ads, social, and on-site promotions.
Budget Management: Allocated resources efficiently across tactics.
Launch Optimization: Tracked performance and refined tactics in real time.

Below is an embedded demonstration of the interactive report:

title: Strategic Marketing
text:
[Project Title 4: Client Consulting & Campaign Optimization]
I collaborated with a client to assess and optimize their existing marketing efforts. Through audits, persona development, and campaign refinement, I helped improve ROI and audience engagement.
Skills Demonstrated:

Client Consulting: Provided clear insights and strategic guidance.
Persona Development: Built target personas to guide messaging.
Campaign Optimization: Identified and addressed areas of underperformance.
Data-Driven Adjustments: Leveraged analytics to refine tactics.

title: Financial Analytics
text:
Below are selected projects that highlight my experience applying financial analytics to real-world challenges. These projects reflect my ability to combine statistical tools, campaign data, and strategic thinking to inform decisions and drive results.
Whether developing dashboards, analyzing historical sales, or uncovering insights, each project is rooted in turning complex finance data into easily interpretable results that can help us predict future sales performance.

title: Financial Analytics
text:
What You’ll Find

Financial Performance Analysis: Evaluating historical sales and order data.
Data Visualization: Turning raw datasets into intuitive dashboards and reports.
Sales Trends: Analysis of year over year sales trends at both the monthly and yearly level.
Customer & Market Insights: Using analytics to predict future sales and staffing needs.

title: Financial Analytics Project
text:
💼 Overview
Below are selected projects that showcase my ability to apply financial analytics to real-world business challenges. These dashboards and analyses reflect a strong foundation in combining statistical modeling, data visualization, and strategic thinking to uncover insights and drive data-informed decisions.
From forecasting future sales to analyzing historical trends, each project demonstrates how complex financial data can be transformed into clear, actionable intelligence that supports business growth and operational planning.


🔍 What You’ll Find

📊 Financial Performance Analysis: Identify patterns, anomalies, and growth opportunities in historical sales and order data.
📈 Data Visualization: Interactive dashboards that transform raw data into decision-ready insights.
📅 Sales Trend Analysis: Year-over-year and seasonal comparisons to uncover performance shifts.
👥 Customer & Market Insights: Segment-level forecasting to guide staffing and inventory strategies.
🔮 Predictive Forecasting: ARIMA-based models to project future sales and support confident planning.

title: Financial Analytics
text:
What You’ll Find

📊 Financial Performance Analysis In-depth evaluation of historical sales and order data to identify patterns, anomalies, and growth opportunities.
📈 Data Visualization Interactive dashboards and visual reports that turn raw datasets into intuitive, decision-ready insights.
📅 Sales Trend Analysis Year-over-year and month-over-month comparisons to highlight seasonal patterns and long-term performance shifts.
👥 Customer & Market Insights Segment-level forecasting and behavioral analysis to anticipate future demand and inform staffing or inventory strategies.
🔮 Predictive Forecasting Time series models (ARIMA) used to project future sales and order volumes, helping teams plan with confidence.

title: Data Exploration and Summaries
text:
This dashboard is built using a sales dataset from Kaggle that captures four years of transactions from a global superstore. Each row represents a unique order, with details spanning customer segments, order and shipping dates, shipping methods, product categories, and sales revenue.
The dataset enables analysis of key business insights including:

Sales trends over time
Product and category profitability
Customer behavior by segment







$2,261,537





4,922





$230.77



These metrics provide a high-level overview of the dataset’s performance.

Total Sales reflects the overall revenue generated.
Number of Orders shows the volume of transactions.
Average Sales per Order helps assess the typical order value.
Together, these figures offer a snapshot of business scale and customer purchasing behavior.







November: $87,540.43December: $80,370.04September: $75,025.85


This section highlights the months with the highest average sales across four years. It reveals seasonal peaks in demand—particularly in November and December, likely due to holiday shopping. This insight is crucial for inventory planning, marketing campaigns, and staffing decisions during high-demand periods.



This chart shows total sales over time, aggregated by month












This line chart shows how total sales have evolved month by month. It helps identify long-term trends, growth patterns, and anomalies in performance. This view is essential for understanding business momentum and for building time series forecasting models.



This section will display a bar plot showing total sales for each product segment.












This bar chart breaks down total sales by customer segment (e.g., Consumer, Corporate, Home Office).
It reveals which segments are the most profitable and where growth opportunities may lie. This information supports targeted marketing and product development strategies.



This shows how sales have changed each year, helping identify growth trends.












This chart compares total sales from one year to the next. It quantifies annual growth rates, helping assess whether the business is expanding or contracting. YoY growth is a key metric for investors, executives, and strategic planning.



This helps identify which months consistently perform better or worse.












This visualization shows how sales vary by month, averaged across all years. It uncovers recurring seasonal patterns, such as spikes in Q4 or dips in summer. Understanding seasonality is vital for forecasting, budgeting, and resource allocation.



This shows how each product category performs over time.












This line chart tracks sales performance for each product category over time. It helps identify category trends, such as rising demand for technology or declining furniture sales.This insight supports product portfolio optimization and category-specific promotions.



This breaks down the sales time series into trend, seasonality, and residuals.












This analysis breaks down the sales time series into three components:

Trend: the long-term direction of sales.
Seasonality: regular, repeating patterns (e.g., monthly or quarterly).
Residuals: random noise or irregular fluctuations.

Time series decomposition is foundational for forecasting models, as it helps isolate predictable patterns from random variation.



This dashboard was created using data from a public Kaggle dataset: Sales Dataset on Kaggle

📊 Financial Forecast Summary

🪑 Furniture – 12-Month Forecast Summary

Total High Estimate: $294,317

Total Expected Forecast: $235,055

Total Low Estimate: $175,790

📈 Peak Month: November 2019

📉 Lowest Month: February 2019

Implications:
Furniture shows moderate growth potential with a strong Q4 peak. Inventory planning should ramp up ahead of November. February may be ideal for cost-saving initiatives or maintenance.
Staffing Note:
Consider scaling fulfillment and delivery staff in Q4. Use February for training or cross-departmental support.


🖇️ Office Supplies – 12-Month Forecast Summary

Total High Estimate: $383,764

Total Expected Forecast: $281,772

Total Low Estimate: $179,783

📈 Peak Month: December 2019

📉 Lowest Month: February 2019

Implications:
Office Supplies show strong seasonal demand, especially in December. This category is highly responsive to B2B and institutional cycles.
Staffing Note:
Prepare for a surge in packaging and customer service in Q4. February may allow for reduced shifts or reallocation to digital support.


💻 Technology – 12-Month Forecast Summary

Total High Estimate: $437,816

Total Expected Forecast: $299,571

Total Low Estimate: $161,328

📈 Peak Month: November 2019

📉 Lowest Month: February 2019

Implications:
Technology is the top-performing category across all forecast scenarios. High-value items drive strong Q4 performance, especially in November.
Staffing Note:
Expand technical support and B2B sales teams ahead of Q4. February may be used for product training or customer retention campaigns.


📈 Overall Forecast Insights

Best Performing Category: Technology (Highest total forecast across all scenarios)
Worst Case Total Sales (All Categories, Low Estimate): $516,901

Expected Total Sales (All Categories): $816,398

Best Case Total Sales (All Categories, High Estimate): $1,115,897

Strategic Takeaways: - Q4 (Oct–Dec) is critical across all categories—plan inventory, staffing, and marketing accordingly. - February is consistently the weakest month—ideal for cost-saving, training, or system upgrades. - Technology should be prioritized for investment, marketing, and enterprise sales focus.



📊 Confidence-Based Actionable Insights

🪑 Furniture – Forecast-Based Actions
Upper Bound (High Sales)
- Increase inventory of top sellers like HON Task Chairs and Riverside Bookcases.
- Expand marketing and sales outreach to corporate clients.
- Staffing: Hire or reassign additional warehouse staff and delivery personnel. Consider temporary staffing for peak months.
Expected Forecast
- Maintain current stock levels and marketing cadence.
- Focus on fulfillment efficiency and customer satisfaction.
- Staffing: Keep staffing steady; cross-train employees to handle multiple roles.
Lower Bound (Low Sales)
- Delay large inventory purchases and reduce marketing spend.
- Offer targeted promotions to stimulate demand.
- Staffing: Reduce overtime or shift hours. Reallocate staff to stronger categories or customer service.


🖇️ Office Supplies – Forecast-Based Actions
Upper Bound (High Sales)
- Stock up on binding machines and consumables.
- Launch B2B subscription programs for recurring orders.
- Staffing: Add fulfillment staff for packaging and shipping. Increase customer support for B2B clients.
Expected Forecast
- Maintain steady supply and pricing.
- Focus on customer retention and upselling.
- Staffing: Maintain current staffing levels. Use part-time or flexible staff to manage fluctuations.
Lower Bound (Low Sales)
- Reduce inventory of slow-moving SKUs.
- Promote digital alternatives or bundle offers.
- Staffing: Consolidate roles or reduce hours in fulfillment. Shift staff to marketing or digital sales support.


💻 Technology – Forecast-Based Actions
Upper Bound (High Sales)
- Prioritize inventory for high-value items like Canon Copiers and Cisco TelePresence.
- Offer premium service packages and enterprise solutions.
- Staffing: Hire or contract technical staff for installations and support. Expand B2B account teams.
Expected Forecast
- Maintain balanced inventory and support resources.
- Focus on upselling accessories and services.
- Staffing: Maintain current staffing. Provide training to improve cross-selling and support.
Lower Bound (Low Sales)
- Delay restocking expensive items.
- Promote trade-in or upgrade programs.
- Staffing: Freeze hiring and reduce hours for technical support. Reassign staff to retention or education roles.



📎 Appendix
This dashboard was created using data from a public Kaggle dataset: Sales Dataset on Kaggle

title: Sales Level Forecasting
text:
📎 Appendix
This dashboard was created using data from a public Kaggle dataset: Sales Dataset on Kaggle

title: Actionable Insights on Forecasted Sales
text:
🪑 Furniture
Forecast Scenario Strategic Actions Upper Bound (High Sales) - Increase inventory of top sellers like HON Task Chairs and Riverside Bookcases. - Expand marketing and sales outreach to corporate clients. - Staffing: Hire or reassign additional warehouse staff and delivery personnel to handle increased volume. Consider temporary staffing for peak months.
Expected Forecast - Maintain current stock levels and marketing cadence. - Focus on fulfillment efficiency and customer satisfaction. - Staffing: Keep staffing steady; cross-train employees to handle multiple roles during moderate surges.
Lower Bound (Low Sales) - Delay large inventory purchases and reduce marketing spend. - Offer targeted promotions to stimulate demand. - Staffing: Reduce overtime or shift hours. Consider reallocating staff to higher-performing categories or customer service roles.

title: Strategic Marketing
section: [Project Title 1: Analyzing SEO Practices: Lululemon vs. Industry Competitors]
text:
[Project Title 1: Analyzing SEO Practices: Lululemon vs. Industry Competitors]
In this project, I conducted a competitive SEO analysis comparing Lululemon with key industry players including Vuori and Athleta. The goal was to evaluate how effectively each brand structures its website content for search engine visibility and user engagement.
Using a reproducible R-based workflow, I scraped and analyzed key webpage types—such as Home, About, Sustainability, and Customer Service pages—to extract and compare title tags and heading structures. I then applied text mining techniques to identify high-frequency bi-grams and keyword patterns across each brand’s content.
This analysis revealed how each brand prioritizes messaging, which terms dominate their SEO strategy, and where Lululemon may be underutilizing high-impact keywords. The findings were visualized through comparative bar charts and word clouds, and summarized in a dashboard-ready report.
Skills Demonstrated:

SEO Strategy & Competitive Benchmarking: Identified keyword gaps and content structure differences across brands.
Text Mining & Web Scraping: Built a reproducible R pipeline to extract and analyze HTML content.
Data Visualization: Created comparative visuals to highlight SEO strengths and weaknesses.
Strategic Recommendations: Delivered actionable insights to improve Lululemon’s content targeting and search visibility.

title: Strategic Marketing
section: Analyzing SEO Practices: Lululemon vs. Industry Competitors
text:
Analyzing SEO Practices: Lululemon vs. Industry Competitors
In this project, I conducted a competitive SEO analysis comparing Lululemon with key industry players including Vuori and Athleta. The goal was to evaluate how effectively each brand structures its website content for search engine visibility and user engagement.
Using a reproducible R-based workflow, I scraped and analyzed key webpage types—such as Home, About, Sustainability, and Customer Service pages—to extract and compare title tags and heading structures. I then applied text mining techniques to identify high-frequency bi-grams and keyword patterns across each brand’s content.
This analysis revealed how each brand prioritizes messaging, which terms dominate their SEO strategy, and where Lululemon may be underutilizing high-impact keywords. The findings were visualized through comparative bar charts and word clouds, and summarized in a dashboard-ready report.
Skills Demonstrated:

SEO Strategy & Competitive Benchmarking: Identified keyword gaps and content structure differences across brands.
Text Mining & Web Scraping: Built a reproducible R pipeline to extract and analyze HTML content.
Data Visualization: Created comparative visuals to highlight SEO strengths and weaknesses.
Strategic Recommendations: Delivered actionable insights to improve Lululemon’s content targeting and search visibility.

title: Analyzing Lululemon SEO Practices Against Competitors
text:
A reproducible research document was developed to systematically scrape and analyze websites from various competitors across four main types of webpages: Home, About, Sustainability, and Customer Service. The table below details the inputs used for this analysis.
The process began by gathering the inputs, which included URLs corresponding to the four page types for each competitor. Each webpage was then scraped to extract headings and title text, resulting in a structured dataset containing these elements for Lululemon, Vuori, and Athleta.
Subsequently, text mining techniques were applied, focusing on bi-gram frequency analysis. Bi-grams (pairs of adjacent words) were generated from the headings and title text found on the webpages. This approach simulates the indexing process performed by search engines, providing insights into the terms and phrases prioritized by different organizations in their digital content.
The reproducible nature of this research document ensures that the analysis can be effortlessly rerun for any company with similar webpages. This flexibility makes it a valuable tool for benchmarking website content and SEO strategies within the context of competitive analysis.

title: Analyzing Lululemon SEO Practices Against Competitors
text:
🧠 Scraping Function

# Load libraries
library(RSelenium)
library(rvest)
library(dplyr)


Attaching package: 'dplyr'


The following objects are masked from 'package:stats':

    filter, lag


The following objects are masked from 'package:base':

    intersect, setdiff, setequal, union

library(tibble)
library(tidyr)
library(knitr)
library(tidytext)
library(stringr)

# Input URLs
seo_pages <- tibble::tibble(
  Brand = c(rep("Lululemon", 4), rep("Vuori", 4), rep("Athleta", 4)),
  Page_Type = rep(c("Home", "About", "Sustainability", "Customer Service"), 3),
  URL = c(
    "https://shop.lululemon.com",
    "https://shop.lululemon.com/about/strategic-sales/corporate",
    "https://shop.lululemon.com/about/responsibility",
    "https://shop.lululemon.com/help",
    "https://vuoriclothing.com",
    "https://vuoriclothing.com/pages/about-us",
    "https://vuoriclothing.com/pages/responsibility",
    "https://vuoriclothing.com/pages/contact-us",
    "https://athleta.gap.com",
    "https://athleta.gap.com/customerService/info.do?cid=2336",
    "https://athleta.gap.com/browse/info.do?cid=1094461",
    "https://athleta.gap.com/customerService/info.do?cid=2336"
  )
)

# Start RSelenium
rD <- rsDriver(browser = "chrome", port = 4545L, chromever = "latest", verbose = FALSE)

Warning in rsDriver(browser = "chrome", port = 4545L, chromever = "latest", :
Could not determine server status.


Could not open chrome browser.


Client error message:
Undefined error in httr call. httr output: Couldn't connect to server [localhost]: Failed to connect to localhost port 4545: Connection refused


Check server log for further details.

remDr <- rD$client

# Scraping function (no URL column returned)
scrape_seo_rselenium <- function(url) {
  tryCatch({
    remDr$navigate(url)
    Sys.sleep(5)
    page_source <- remDr$getPageSource()[[1]]
    page <- read_html(page_source)

    tibble(
      h1 = page %>% html_elements("h1") %>% html_text(trim = TRUE) %>% paste(collapse = " | "),
      h2 = page %>% html_elements("h2") %>% html_text(trim = TRUE) %>% paste(collapse = " | "),
      h3 = page %>% html_elements("h3") %>% html_text(trim = TRUE) %>% paste(collapse = " | "),
      h4 = page %>% html_elements("h4") %>% html_text(trim = TRUE) %>% paste(collapse = " | "),
      h5 = page %>% html_elements("h5") %>% html_text(trim = TRUE) %>% paste(collapse = " | "),
      h6 = page %>% html_elements("h6") %>% html_text(trim = TRUE) %>% paste(collapse = " | "),
      titleText = page %>% html_element("title") %>% html_text(trim = TRUE)
    )
  }, error = function(e) {
    message(paste("Failed to scrape:", url))
    return(tibble(h1=NA, h2=NA, h3=NA, h4=NA, h5=NA, h6=NA, titleText=NA))
  })
}

# Scrape all pages
seo_data <- seo_pages %>%
  rowwise() %>%
  mutate(data = list(scrape_seo_rselenium(URL))) %>%
  unnest(cols = c(data), names_sep = "_") %>%
  ungroup()

Failed to scrape: https://shop.lululemon.com


Failed to scrape: https://shop.lululemon.com/about/strategic-sales/corporate


Failed to scrape: https://shop.lululemon.com/about/responsibility


Failed to scrape: https://shop.lululemon.com/help


Failed to scrape: https://vuoriclothing.com


Failed to scrape: https://vuoriclothing.com/pages/about-us


Failed to scrape: https://vuoriclothing.com/pages/responsibility


Failed to scrape: https://vuoriclothing.com/pages/contact-us


Failed to scrape: https://athleta.gap.com


Failed to scrape: https://athleta.gap.com/customerService/info.do?cid=2336


Failed to scrape: https://athleta.gap.com/browse/info.do?cid=1094461


Failed to scrape: https://athleta.gap.com/customerService/info.do?cid=2336

# Stop RSelenium safely
tryCatch({
  remDr$close()
  rD$server$stop()
}, error = function(e) message("RSelenium session already closed or failed to start."))

RSelenium session already closed or failed to start.

# Split by page type
home_data <- filter(seo_data, Page_Type == "Home")
about_data <- filter(seo_data, Page_Type == "About")
sustainability_data <- filter(seo_data, Page_Type == "Sustainability")
customer_service_data <- filter(seo_data, Page_Type == "Customer Service")

# SEO summary function
generate_seo_summary <- function(data, page_name) {
  heading_counts <- data %>%
    select(starts_with("data_h")) %>%
    summarise(across(everything(), ~ sum(!is.na(.) & . != ""))) %>%
    pivot_longer(cols = everything(), names_to = "Heading", values_to = "Count")

  all_text <- data %>%
    select(starts_with("data_h"), data_titleText) %>%
    pivot_longer(cols = everything(), values_to = "text") %>%
    filter(!is.na(text)) %>%
    pull(text) %>%
    paste(collapse = " ")

  bigrams <- tibble(text = all_text) %>%
    unnest_tokens(bigram, text, token = "ngrams", n = 2) %>%
    count(bigram, sort = TRUE) %>%
    filter(n > 1)

  cat("###", page_name, "\n\n")
  cat("**Heading Structure:**\n")
  print(kable(heading_counts))

  cat("\n**Most Frequent Bi-grams:**\n")
  print(kable(head(bigrams, 10)))

  cat("\n**SEO Observations:**\n")
  cat("- Title text could be more specific and keyword-rich.\n")
  cat("- Consider emphasizing terms like 'donations', 'training', or 'certification' if relevant.\n")
  cat("- Ensure high-level headings (H1, H2) reflect core mission and services.\n\n")
}

# Run analysis
generate_seo_summary(home_data, "Home Page")

### Home Page 

**Heading Structure:**


|Heading | Count|
|:-------|-----:|
|data_h1 |     0|
|data_h2 |     0|
|data_h3 |     0|
|data_h4 |     0|
|data_h5 |     0|
|data_h6 |     0|

**Most Frequent Bi-grams:**


|bigram |  n|
|:------|--:|

**SEO Observations:**
- Title text could be more specific and keyword-rich.
- Consider emphasizing terms like 'donations', 'training', or 'certification' if relevant.
- Ensure high-level headings (H1, H2) reflect core mission and services.

- Ensure high-level headings (H1, H2) reflect core mission and services.
